body: If the past 12 months have taught us anything, itโs that the AI hype train is showing no signs of slowing. Itโs hard to believe that at the beginning of the year, DeepSeek had yet to turn the entire industry on its head, Meta was better known for trying (and failing) to make the metaverse cool than for its relentless quest to dominate superintelligence, and vibe coding wasnโt a thing. If thatโs left you feeling a little confused, fear not. As we near the end of 2025, our writers have taken a look back over the AI terms that dominated the year, for better or worse. Make sure you take the time to brace yourself for what promises to be another bonkers year. โRhiannon Williams 1. Superintelligence As long as people have been  hyping  AI, they have been coming up with names for a future, ultra-powerful form of the technology that could bring about utopian or  dystopian  consequences for humanity. โSuperintelligenceโ is that latest hot term. Meta  announced  in July that it would form an AI team to pursue superintelligence, and it was reportedly offering nine-figure compensation packages to AI experts from the companyโs competitors to join. title: Meet the man hunting the spies in your smartphone
summary: In April 2025, Ronald Deibert left all electronic devices at home in Toronto and boarded a plane. When he landed in Illinois, he took a taxi to a mall and headed directly to the Apple Store to purchase a new laptop and iPhone. Heโd wanted to keep the risk of having his personal devices confiscatedโฆ
body: In April 2025, Ronald Deibert left all electronic devices at home in Toronto and boarded a plane. When he landed in Illinois, he took a taxi to a mall and headed directly to the Apple Store to purchase a new laptop and iPhone. Heโd wanted to keep the risk of having his personal devices confiscated to a minimum, because he knew his work made him a prime target for surveillance. โIโm traveling under the assumption that I am being watched, right down to exactly where I am at any moment,โ Deibert says. Deibert directs the Citizen Lab, a research center he founded in 2001 to serve as โcounterintelligence for civil society.โ Housed at the University of Toronto, the lab operates independently of governments or corporate interests, relying instead on research grants and private philanthropy for financial support. Itโs one of the few institutions that investigate cyberthreats exclusively in the public interest, and in doing so, it has exposed some of the most egregious digital abuses of the past two decades. For many years, Deibert and his colleagues have held up the US as the standard for liberal democracy. But thatโs changing, he says: โThe pillars of democracy are under assault in the Uโฆ

title: Four bright spots in climate news in 2025
summary: Climate news hasnโt been great in 2025. Global greenhouse-gas emissions hit record highs (again). This year is set to be either the second or third warmest on record. Climate-fueled disasters like wildfires in California and flooding in Indonesia and Pakistan devastated communities and caused billiโฆ
body: Climate news hasnโt been great in 2025. Global greenhouse-gas emissions hit record highs (again). This year is set to be either the second or third warmest on record. Climate-fueled disasters like wildfires in California and flooding in Indonesia and Pakistan devastated communities and caused billions in damage. In addition to these worrying indicators of our continued contributions to climate change and their obvious effects, the worldโs largest economy has made a sharp U-turn on climate policy this year. The US under the Trump administration withdrew from the Paris Agreement , cut funds for climate research , and scrapped billions of dollars in funding for climate tech projects. Weโre in a severe situation with climate change. But for those looking for bright spots, there was some good news in 2025. Here are a few of the positive stories our climate reporters noticed this year. Chinaโs flattening emissions GETTY IMAGES One of the most notable and encouraging signs of progress this year occurred in China. The worldโs second-biggest economy and biggest climate polluter has managed to keep carbon dioxide emissions flat for the last year and a half, according to an analysis in Carboโฆ

title: Researchers are getting organoids pregnant with human embryos
summary: At first glance, it looks like the start of a human pregnancy: A ball-shaped embryo presses gently into the receptive lining of the uterus and then grips tight, burrowing in as the first tendrils of a future placenta appear. This is implantationโthe moment that pregnancy officially begins. Only nonโฆ
body: At first glance, it looks like the start of a human pregnancy: A ball-shaped embryo presses gently into the receptive lining of the uterus and then grips tight, burrowing in as the first tendrils of a future placenta appear.  This is implantationโthe moment that pregnancy officially begins. Only none of it is happening inside a body. These images were captured in a Beijing laboratory, inside a microfluidic chip, as scientists watched the scene unfold. This transparent microfluidic chip is used to grow an organoid that mimics the lining of a uterus. COURTESY OF THE RESEARCHERS In three papers published this week by Cell Press, scientists are reporting what they call the most accurate efforts yet to mimic the first moments of pregnancy in the lab. Theyโve taken human embryos from IVF centers and let these merge with โorganoidsโ made of endometrial cells, which form the lining of the uterus. The reportsโtwo from China and a third involving a collaboration among researchers in the United Kingdom, Spain, and the USโshow how scientists are using engineered tissues to better understand early pregnancy and potentially improve IVF outcomes. โYou have an embryo and the endometrial orgaโฆ

title: How social media encourages the worst of AI boosterism
summary: Demis Hassabis, CEO of Google DeepMind, summed it up in three words: โThis is embarrassing.โ Hassabis was replying on X to an overexcited post by Sรฉbastien Bubeck, a research scientist at the rival firm OpenAI, announcing that two mathematicians had used OpenAIโs latest large language model, GPT-5,โฆ
body: Demis Hassabis, CEO of Google DeepMind, summed it up in three words : โThis is embarrassing.โ   Hassabis was replying on X to an overexcited post by Sรฉbastien Bubeck, a research scientist at the rival firm OpenAI, announcing that two mathematicians had used OpenAIโs latest large language model, GPT-5, to find solutions to 10 unsolved problems in mathematics. โScience acceleration via AI has officially begun,โ Bubeck crowed. Put your math hats on for a minute, and letโs take a look at what this beef from mid-October was about. Itโs a perfect example of whatโs wrong with AI right now. Bubeck was excited that GPT-5 seemed to have somehow solved a number of puzzles known as Erdลs problems. Paul Erdลs, one of the most prolific mathematicians of the 20th century, left behind hundreds of puzzles when he died. To help keep track of which ones have been solved, Thomas Bloom, a mathematician at the University of Manchester, UK, set up erdosproblems.com , which lists more than 1,100 problems and notes that around 430 of them come with solutions.  When Bubeck celebrated GPT-5โs breakthrough, Bloom was quick to call him out . โThis is a dramatic misrepresentation,โ he wrote on Xโฆ

title: How I learned to stop worrying and love AI slop
summary: Lately, everywhere I scroll, I keep seeing the same fish-eyed CCTV view: a grainy wide shot from the corner of a living room, a driveway at night, an empty grocery store. Then something impossible happens. JD Vance shows up at the doorstep in a crazy outfit. A car folds into itself like paper and dโฆ
body: Lately, everywhere I scroll, I keep seeing the same fish-eyed CCTV view: a grainy wide shot from the corner of a living room, a driveway at night, an empty grocery store. Then something impossible happens. JD Vance shows up at the doorstep in a crazy outfit. A car folds into itself like paper and drives away. A cat comes in and starts hanging out with capybaras and bears, as if in some weird modern fairy tale. This fake-surveillance look has become one of the signature flavors of what people now call AI slop. For those of us who spend time online watching short videos, slop feels inescapable: a flood of repetitive, often nonsensical AI-generated clips that washes across TikTok, Instagram, and beyond. For that, you can thank new tools like OpenAIโs Sora (which exploded in popularity after launching in app form in September), Googleโs Veo series, and AI models built by Runway. Now anyone can make videos , with just a few taps on a screen.  @absolutemem If I were to locate the moment slop broke through into popular consciousness, Iโd pick the video of rabbits bouncing on a trampoline that went viral this summer. For many savvy internet users, myself included, it was the first tiโฆ

title: Welcome to Kenyaโs Great Carbon Valley: a bold new gamble to fight climate change
summary: The earth around Lake Naivasha, a shallow freshwater basin in south-central Kenya, does not seem to want to lie still. Ash from nearby Mount Longonot, which erupted as recently as the 1860s, remains in the ground. Obsidian caves and jagged stone towers preside over the steam that spurts out of fissโฆ
body: The earth around Lake Naivasha, a shallow freshwater basin in south-central Kenya, does not seem to want to lie still.  Ash from nearby Mount Longonot, which erupted as recently as the 1860s, remains in the ground. Obsidian caves and jagged stone towers preside over the steam that spurts out of fissures in the soil and wafts from pools of boiling-hot waterโproduced by magma that, in some areas, sits just a few miles below the surface.  Itโs a landscape born from violent geologic processes some 25 million years ago, when the Nubian and Somalian tectonic plates pulled apart. That rupture cut a depression in the earth some 4,000 miles longโfrom East Africa up through the Middle Eastโto create whatโs now called the Great Rift Valley.  This volatility imbues the land with vast potential, much of it untapped. The area, no more than a few hoursโ drive from Nairobi, is home to five geothermal power stations, which harness the clouds of steam to generate about a quarter of Kenyaโs electricity. But some energy from this process escapes into the atmosphere, while even more remains underground for lack of demand.  Thatโs what brought Octavia Carbon here.  In June, jusโฆ

title: China figured out how to sell EVs. Now it has to deal with their aging batteries.
summary: In August 2025, Wang Lei decided it was finally time to say goodbye to his electric vehicle. Wang, who is 39, had bought the car in 2016, when EVs still felt experimental in Beijing. It was a compact Chinese brand. The subsidies were good, and the salesman talked about โsupporting domestic innovatiโฆ
body: In August 2025, Wang Lei decided it was finally time to say goodbye to his electric vehicle. Wang, who is 39, had bought the car in 2016, when EVs still felt experimental in Beijing. It was a compact Chinese brand. The subsidies were good, and the salesman talked about โsupporting domestic innovation.โ At the time, only a few people around him were driving on batteries. He liked being early. But now, the carโs range had started to shrink as the batteryโs health declined. He could have replaced the battery, but the warranty had expired; the cost and trouble no longer felt worth it. He also wanted an upgrade, so selling became the obvious choice. His vague plans turned into action after he started seeing ads on Douyin from local battery recyclers. He asked around at a few recycling places, and the highest offer came from a smaller shop on the outskirts of town. He added the contact on WeChat, and the next day someone drove over to pick up his car. He got paid 8,000 yuan. With the additional automobile scrappage subsidy offered by the Chinese government, Wang ultimately pocketed about 28,000 yuan. Wang is part of a much larger trend. In the past decade, China has seen an EV boom, thaโฆ
